'''Courtney Marie Andrews''' (born November 7, 1990) is an American singer-songwriter originally from [[Phoenix, Arizona]].<ref name="java">{{cite magazine
|url=http://www.javamagaz.com/Oct2008/Page36and37.html
|title=Know Your Locals
|last=Drew
|first=Cline
|date=October 2008
|magazine=Java Magazine
|accessdate=January 3, 2011
|url-status=dead
|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120220060818/http://www.javamagaz.com/Oct2008/Page36and37.html
|archive-date=February 20, 2012
}}</ref> She released her first widely distributed and breakthrough studio album, ''[[Honest Life]]'', in 2016. From 2010 to 2011, Andrews was an auxiliary member of [[Jimmy Eat World]], appearing on their 2010 studio album ''[[Invented (album)|Invented]]'' and acting as their keyboardist and backing vocalist on the subsequent tour.<ref name="coup">{{cite magazine |url=http://www.coupdemainmagazine.com/music/tidbits/2643-jimmy-eat-world-plus-courtney-marie-andrews-performing-an-acoustic-version-of-coffee-and-cigarettes-live|title=Jimmy Eat World Plus Courtney Marie Andrews Performing an Acoustic Version of Coffee and Cigarettes Live|last=Mudgway|first=Sarah|date=January 12, 2011|accessdate=January 3, 2011|url-status=dead|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110708200354/http://www.coupdemainmagazine.com/music/tidbits/2643-jimmy-eat-world-plus-courtney-marie-andrews-performing-an-acoustic-version-of-coffee-and-cigarettes-live|archive-date=July 8, 2011|magazine=Coup de Main Magazine}}</ref>

==History==
===Early years===
Andrews began playing guitar and writing songs at the age of 13 or 14<ref name="java"/><ref name="teen">{{cite news|url=http://www.phoenixnewtimes.com/2009-07-30/music/courtney-marie-andrews-gives-a-glimpse-into-a-teen-girl-s-world|title=Courtney Marie Andrews Gives a Glimpse into a Teen Girl's World|last=Meyer|first=Mike|date=July 30, 2009|newspaper=[[Phoenix New Times]]|accessdate=April 12, 2010|archive-date=March 16, 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150316205950/http://www.phoenixnewtimes.com/2009-07-30/music/courtney-marie-andrews-gives-a-glimpse-into-a-teen-girl-s-world/|url-status=dead}}</ref> and began performing at 15.

In September 2009, [[Jim Adkins]] of the band [[Jimmy Eat World]] asked Andrews to sing with him on a live cover of [[Wilco]] and [[Feist (singer)|Feist]]'s song "You and I".<ref>{{cite news|last= Jansen|first= Steve|date= April 8, 2010|title= By the Time I Get to Phoenix: Courtney Marie Andrews Is the Biggest Star in the Valley's Blooming Pop-Folk Scene|url= http://www.phoenixnewtimes.com/2010-04-08/news/by-the-time-i-get-to-phoenix-courtney-marie-andrews-is-the-biggest-star-in-the-valley-s-blooming-pop-folk-scene/2/|newspaper= Phoenix New Times|access-date= April 22, 2015|archive-date= November 13, 2013|archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20131113102942/http://www.phoenixnewtimes.com/2010-04-08/news/by-the-time-i-get-to-phoenix-courtney-marie-andrews-is-the-biggest-star-in-the-valley-s-blooming-pop-folk-scene/2/|url-status= dead}}</ref> In 2010, she recorded backing vocals for Jimmy Eat World<ref name="UG">{{cite web|url=http://www.ultimate-guitar.com/interviews/interviews/jimmy_eat_world_have_little_complaints_about_their_new_album.html|title=Jimmy Eat World: Have Little Complaints About Their New Album|publisher=[[Ultimate-Guitar.com]]|author=Rosen, Steven|accessdate=April 22, 2015|archive-date=October 8, 2012|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121008181707/http://www.ultimate-guitar.com/interviews/interviews/jimmy_eat_world_have_little_complaints_about_their_new_album.html|url-status=dead}}</ref> on five songs for their studio album ''[[Invented (album)|Invented]]''. She subsequently joined them on stage to perform during the album's release and full 2010–2011 tours, acting as their keyboardist and backing vocalist.<ref name="coup"/><ref name="jimeat">{{cite web|last1=Pareles|first1=Jon|title=Jimmy Eat World Plays Terminal 5|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/10/16/arts/music/16jimmy.html|website=The New York Times|accessdate=March 1, 2018|date=October 15, 2010}}</ref>

In 2011, Andrews relocated to [[Seattle]], [[Washington (state)|Washington]]. It was there that she began playing electric guitar in long-time admirer [[Damien Jurado]]'s band.

===''Honest Life''===
It was while living in Belgium for four months playing guitar and singing with Belgian star [[Milow]] that the songs for ''[[Honest Life]]'', Andrews' fifth studio album, started taking shape. Written on the back of heartbreak and homesickness, ''Honest Life'' tells the story of Andrews' first true growing pains as a woman, the desire to fit somewhere when nowhere fits and the longing to return home to the people she knows and loves. The album was produced entirely by Andrews at Litho Studios in Seattle with audio engineer Floyd Reitsma and was released on August 19, 2016, in North America by Mama Bird Recording Co. and on January 20, 2017, in the UK and Europe by [[Loose Music|Loose]].

It was well received by US critics. In addition to being ''The Bluegrass Situation's'' Album of the Year,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thebluegrasssituation.com/read/bgs-class-2016-albums|title=BGS Class of 2016: Albums|date=December 15, 2016|website=Thebluegrasssituation.com}}</ref> ''[[Rolling Stone]]'' named ''Honest Life'' one of the Top 40 country albums of 2016<ref>{{cite magazine|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/country/lists/40-best-country-albums-of-2016-w452950/courtney-marie-andrews-honest-life-w453939|title=40 Best Country Albums of 2016|magazine=[[Rolling Stone]]}}</ref> as well as naming Andrews one of ten new country artists people need to know.<ref>{{cite magazine|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/country/lists/10-new-country-artists-you-need-to-know-november-2016-w448819/courtney-marie-andrews-w448830|title=10 New Country Artists You Need to Know Right Now|magazine=[[Rolling Stone]]}}</ref> ''[[Stereogum]]'' praised Andrews' songwriting, calling it "an expert marriage of gracefully confessional songwriting with country-folk arrangements that recall [[Joni Mitchell]]" while naming ''Honest Life'' the No. 6 best country album of 2016.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.stereogum.com/1916713/the-20-best-country-albums-of-2016/franchises/2016-in-review/|title=The 20 Best Country Albums Of 2016|date=December 16, 2016|website=Stereogum.com}}</ref> While naming it the No. 38 best album of 2016,<ref>{{cite web|url=https://americansongwriter.com/2016/12/top-50-albums-2016/2/|title=American Songwriter's Top 50 Albums Of 2016: Presented by D'addario « Page 2 of 5 « American Songwriter|date=December 1, 2016|website=Americansongwriter.com|access-date=January 4, 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190421154613/https://americansongwriter.com/2016/12/top-50-albums-2016/2/|archive-date=April 21, 2019|url-status=dead}}</ref> ''[[American Songwriter]]'' called the single "How Quickly Your Heart Mends" the No. 4 song of 2016<ref>{{cite web|url=https://americansongwriter.com/2016/12/top-50-songs-2016-presented-bose/5/|title=Top 50 Songs of 2016: Presented By Bose « Page 5 of 5 « American Songwriter|date=December 7, 2016|website=Americansongwriter.com|access-date=January 4, 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171202203149/https://americansongwriter.com/2016/12/top-50-songs-2016-presented-bose/5/|archive-date=December 2, 2017|url-status=dead}}</ref> and continued to praise Andrews' songwriting saying "she writes with such empathy and insight that she gives Lucinda a run for her money". The single "Rookie Dreaming" was placed on the year end Heavy Rotation list by [[NPR]] and was placed on their "Folk Alley's 10 Favorite Albums of 2016" list.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.npr.org/2016/12/19/505270066/folk-alleys-10-favorite-albums-of-2016|title=Folk Alley's 10 Favorite Albums Of 2016|website=Npr.org|date=December 19, 2016 |last1=See |first1=Elena |last2=Fahey |first2=Linda }}</ref>

Upon its release in the UK/EU, ''Honest Life'' reached No. 1 on the Official UK Americana Chart and No. 1 on the Independent Album Breakers Chart after the first week. It received a five-star review from ''[[The Daily Telegraph]]''<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/music/what-to-listen-to/courtney-marie-andrews-honest-life-review/|title=A country star from another age: Courtney Marie Andrews, Honest Life, review|first=Neil|last=McCormick|date=December 2, 2017|website=Telegraph.co.uk}}</ref> who called it "an absolutely perfect little gem of an album" and four-star reviews from both ''[[Mojo (magazine)|Mojo]]'' and ''[[Q (magazine)|Q]]'' magazines.

On April 11, Courtney performed "Table for One" and "Honest Life" on ''[[Later... with Jools Holland]]''.  She was joined by pedal steel guitarist [[B. J. Cole]] on both songs and [[Jools Holland]] joined the pair on "Honest Life".

===''May Your Kindness Remain''===
[[File:Courtney Marie Andrews 01 04 2017 -3 (32127956886).jpg|thumb|Andrews performing in 2016]]
''[[May Your Kindness Remain]]'' is Andrews' sixth studio album and the follow-up to her breakthrough studio album, ''Honest Life''. The album was released on March 23, 2018, in the UK and Europe by [[Loose Music|Loose]] and the rest of the world by [[Fat Possum Records]] and Mama Bird Recording Co. Produced by [[Mark Howard (producer)|Mark Howard]] ([[Lucinda Williams]], [[Bob Dylan]], [[Emmylou Harris]], [[Tom Waits]]), the album was recorded over eight days at a rented house-turned-studio in Los Angeles, California. In addition to Andrews on vocals and electric and acoustic guitar, the album features Dillon Warnek (electric guitar), Daniel Walter (organ, [[Wurlitzer]], accordion), Charles Wicklander (piano, Wurlitzer), William Mapp (drums, percussion), Alex Sabel (bass) and C.C. White (backing vocals).

Of the album and the inspiration behind its ten songs, Andrews comments, "The people that I've met on the road these past few years got me thinking about my childhood, and the people around me that I've known, and the stories that come from my family. It became clear how many people are struggling through the same issues. People are constantly chasing that bigger life. A lot of people are poor in America—and because of those unattainable goals, they're also mentally unstable, or sad, or depressed or unfulfilled. A lot of people—myself included at some point in my life—are loving somebody through this. That's sort of the theme of the record: coming to terms with depression and the reality of the world we're living in."

''May Your Kindness Remain'' received critical acclaim for its release in the United States from ''Rolling Stone'', NPR Music, ''[[Chicago Tribune]]'', ''[[American Songwriter]]'', WXPN The Key, ''Bluegrass Situation'' and more. Of the single and Andrews, ''[[The Fader|Fader]]'' declares "Kindness of Strangers' rules...incredible cut...what a voice she has – it always lifts me up"<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.thefader.com/2018/01/31/courtney-marie-andrews-kindness-of-strangers|title=Listen to this Courtney Marie Andrews country song please|work=The FADER|access-date=April 9, 2018|language=en}}</ref> and ''[[Paste (magazine)|Paste]]'' magazine recounts that the album is "a rare blend of power and feeling that can bring you to your knees".<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.pastemagazine.com/articles/2018/03/courtney-marie-andrews-may-your-kindness-remain-re.html|title=Courtney Marie Andrews: May Your Kindness Remain Review|work=pastemagazine.com|access-date=April 9, 2018|language=en}}</ref> Naming ''May Your Kindness Remain'' as the album of the week, ''[[Stereogum]]'' describes the album as "...a head-spinning discovery, a warm and gorgeous and fully formed piece of work. The kindness isn't just in the lyrics. It's in the way music like this can nourish you, can make your insides glow. An album like this can be a refuge,"<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.stereogum.com/1987685/album-of-the-week-courtney-marie-andrews-may-your-kindness-remain/franchises/album-of-the-week/|title=Album Of The Week: Courtney Marie Andrews May Your Kindness Remain|date=March 2, 2018|work=Stereogum|access-date=April 9, 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180409233646/https://www.stereogum.com/1987685/album-of-the-week-courtney-marie-andrews-may-your-kindness-remain/franchises/album-of-the-week/|archive-date=April 9, 2018|url-status=dead}}</ref> while ''[[BrooklynVegan]]'' describes the album as "more proof that Courtney is a force to be reckoned with".<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.brooklynvegan.com/courtney-marie-andrews-announces-new-album-tour-shares-title-track/ |title=Courtney Marie Andrews announces new album and tour, shares title track |last=Sacher |first=Andrew |date=January 10, 2018 |website=[[BrooklynVegan]] |access-date=October 28, 2020}}</ref>

Upon its release in Europe, ''May Your Kindness Remain'' received No. 1 placement on the Euro Americana Chart for April 2018,<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.euroamericanachart.eu/archive_2016?field_month_tid=4&field_year_value=5|title=Monthly list {{!}} EuroAmericanaChart|website=Euroamericanachart.eu|language=en|access-date=April 9, 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180409233441/http://www.euroamericanachart.eu/archive_2016?field_month_tid=4&field_year_value=5|archive-date=April 9, 2018|url-status=dead}}</ref> as well as placing No. 1 on the UK Americana Albums Charts, UK Independent Albums Breakers Charts, No. 5 on the UK Independent Albums Chart. ''[[The Daily Telegraph]]'' called the album "another absolute beauty, a set of nuanced, compassionate portraits and vignettes of good people in difficult circumstances".<ref>{{Cite news|title=Courtney Marie Andrews, interview: 'I'm optimistic about America's working class'|last=McCormick|first=Neil|date=February 11, 2018|work=The Daily Telegraph|language=en-GB|issn=0307-1235}}</ref> Additionally, ''MYKR'' placed in at No. 19 in Sweden for general music charts upon its release. The album received positive reception in the United States as well, placing No. 12 on the US Top New Artist Albums Chart and No. 14 on the US [[Americana/Folk Albums]] chart. Andrews subsequently received the "International Artist of the Year" award by the UK Americana Awards for ''May Your Kindness Remain'' in February 2018.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.loosemusic.com/courtneymarieandrews/courtney-marie-andrews-crowned-international-artist-of-the-year-at-the-uk-americana-awards|title=Loose {{!}} Courtney Marie Andrews Crowned 'International Artist of the Year' At The UK Americana Awards|website=www.loosemusic.com|language=en-GB|access-date=September 17, 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180917215516/https://www.loosemusic.com/courtneymarieandrews/courtney-marie-andrews-crowned-international-artist-of-the-year-at-the-uk-americana-awards|archive-date=September 17, 2018|url-status=dead}}</ref>

On March 31, 2018, following the release of ''May Your Kindness Remain'', Andrews made her US national television debut on ''[[CBS Saturday Morning|CBS This Morning Saturday]]'' where she performed "May Your Kindness Remain", "Kindness of Strangers", and "Two Cold Nights in Buffalo". Shortly after, the band appeared on [[NPR]]'s ''[[World Cafe (radio program)|World Cafe]]'' series performing the album's title track.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.npr.org/sections/world-cafe/2018/04/10/600237469/courtney-marie-andrews-on-world-cafe|title=Courtney Marie Andrews On World Cafe|work=NPR.org|access-date=June 6, 2018|language=en}}</ref> In May 2018, Andrews was nominated for "Emerging Artist of the Year" by the [[Americana Music Association]] in the United States.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://americanamusic.org/news/americana-announces-2018-honors-awards-nominees|title=Americana Announces 2018 Honors & Awards Nominees {{!}} AmericanaMusic.org|website=americanamusic.org|date=May 14, 2018 |language=en|access-date=September 17, 2018}}</ref> She later performed on air at the [[Americana Music Honors & Awards|Americana Music and Honors awards]] ceremony on September 13, 2018, at the legendary [[Ryman Auditorium]] in Nashville, Tennessee.<ref>{{Cite magazine|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-country/2018-americana-honors-awards-how-to-watch-performers-nominees-722964/|title=2018 Americana Honors & Awards: How to Watch, Performers, Nominees|last=Crawford|first=Robert|date=September 1, 2018|magazine=Rolling Stone|access-date=September 17, 2018|language=en-US}}</ref>

In June 2018, ''Rolling Stone'' named ''May Your Kindness Remain'' as one of the 25 Best Country and Americana Albums of 2018.<ref>{{Cite magazine|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/country/lists/25-best-country-and-americana-albums-of-2018-so-far-w521622|title=25 Best Country and Americana Albums of 2018 So Far|magazine=Rolling Stone|access-date=June 20, 2018}}</ref> In the United Kingdom, ''[[The Guardian]]'' similarly called the album one of the 25 Best Albums of 2018.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/music/2018/jun/20/best-albums-of-2018-so-far|title=Best albums of 2018 so far|last=Beaumont-Thomas|first=Ben|date=June 2, 2018|work=The Guardian|access-date=June 20, 2018|language=en-GB|issn=0261-3077}}</ref>

===''Old Flowers''===
Andrews released her seventh studio album ''[[Old Flowers]]'' on July 24, 2020, via [[Fat Possum Records]]/[[Loose Music|Loose]].<ref>{{cite web|last1=Uitti|first1=Jacob|date=July 22, 2020|title=Courtney Marie Andrews Shares What Went Into Making 'Old Flowers'|url=https://americansongwriter.com/old-flowers-courtney-marie-andrews-album-interview/|accessdate=July 24, 2020|website=American Songwriter}}</ref> The album initially had a June release date, but Andrews moved its release back due to the [[COVID-19 pandemic]]'s impact on vinyl record production and independent record stores.<ref>{{cite web |title=Courtney Marie Andrews' new album Old Flowers is delayed, but watch "Burlap String" video and pre-order from a local record store |url=https://thekey.xpn.org/2020/05/01/courtney-marie-andrews-2020/ |website=The Key |accessdate=July 24, 2020 |language=en |date=May 1, 2020}}</ref> The album was met with immediate critical acclaim from ''[[The New York Times]]''<ref>{{Cite news|last1=Pareles|first1=Jon|last2=Caramanica|first2=Jon|last3=Russonello|first3=Giovanni|date=July 2, 2020|title=Taylor Swift's Heartbreak Dreamscape, and 9 More New Songs|language=en-US|work=The New York Times|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2020/07/24/arts/music/playlist-taylor-swift-j-cole-drake.html|access-date=July 28, 2020|issn=0362-4331}}</ref> and it received 5 stars from ''[[The Times]]''.<ref>{{Cite news|last=Hodgkinson|first=Will|title=Courtney Marie Andrews: Old Flowers review — blue-collar beauty|newspaper=[[The Times]] |language=en|url=https://www.thetimes.co.uk/article/courtney-marie-andrews-old-flowers-review-blue-collar-beauty-rgbmc55k8|access-date=July 28, 2020|issn=0140-0460}}</ref> ''[[Rolling Stone]]'' described the single "It Must Be Someone Else's Fault" as bringing "to mind classic [[Bob Dylan]] and [[Joni Mitchell]], but Andrews' bell-clear voice and fearless message of introspection are unmistakably her own".<ref>{{Cite magazine|last=Freeman|first=Jon|date=May 2, 2020|title=Courtney Marie Andrews Releases 'It Must Be Someone Else's Fault' Video|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-country/courtney-marie-andrews-it-must-be-someone-elses-fault-video-1005935/|access-date=July 28, 2020|magazine=Rolling Stone|language=en-US}}</ref>

The album received a nomination for [[Grammy Award for Best Americana Album|Best Americana Album]] at the [[63rd Annual Grammy Awards]].<ref name="grammy">{{cite web |url=https://www.grammy.com/grammys/awards/winners-nominees/273 |title=Grammy Awards Winners & Nominees for Best Americana Album |author=<!--Not stated--> |date=2021 |website=grammy.com |publisher=Recording Academy |access-date=March 15, 2021}}</ref>

In July 2021 she participated as a solo artist at the [[Newport Folk Festival]].<ref>{{Cite web |title=Newport Folk Festival stage schedule 2021 |url=https://newportfolk.org/2021-schedule/ |access-date=2021-09-21 |website=newportfolk.org}}</ref>

===''Old Monarch''===
Andrews' debut poetry collection, ''Old Monarch,'' was published by Andrews McMeel Publishing in 2021.<ref>{{Cite web|title=Old Monarch|url=https://publishing.andrewsmcmeel.com/book/old-monarch/|access-date=2021-11-23|website=Andrews McMeel Publishing|language=en-US}}</ref> ''Cleveland Review of Books'' said the collection "taps into the folklores of the American frontier".<ref>{{Cite web|title=Heartbreak Haptics: On Courtney Marie Andrews' "Old Monarch"|url=https://www.clereviewofbooks.com/home/courtney-marie-andrews-old-monarch-review|access-date=2021-11-23|website=Cleveland Review of Books|language=en-US}}</ref>

=== ''Loose Future'' ===
Andrews' eighth studio album was released in October 2022 under [[Fat Possum Records]]. Written from a beach shack on Cape Cod, a summer of introspection led to the inception of ''Loose Future''.<ref name="Erlewine">{{Cite web |last=Erlewine |first=Stephen Thomas |title=Loose Future: Courtney Marie Andrews |date=October 18, 2022 |url=https://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/courtney-marie-andrews-loose-future/ |access-date=2024-01-19 |website=Pitchfork |language=en-US}}</ref> 

In partnership with [[Sam Evian]], a producer who has previously worked with [[Big Thief]] and [[Cassandra Jenkins]], Andrews was able to expand her aural palate and transition into a new sonic world. Pitchfork asserts that "the smooth, radiant production doesn't amount to commercial pandering: it's assured, exploratory, and warm music that mirrors Andrews' newly opened heart."<ref name="Erlewine" />

On ''Loose Future'', "Andrews channels her Pop influences to make her brightest, freest songs to date."<ref>{{Cite web |title=Walking on sunshine with Courtney Marie Andrews |url=https://www.thelineofbestfit.com/features/interviews/courtney-marie-andrews-walking-on-sunshine |access-date=2024-01-20 |website=The Line of Best Fit |language=en-US}}</ref> The ten-track album "is about freedom, renewal, self-love and saving commitment for tomorrow".<ref>{{Cite news |last=Jack |first=Malcolm |date=2022-10-12 |title='I wanted it to sound like that feeling of possibility': Courtney Marie Andrews' freewheeling new album |url=https://www.theguardian.com/music/2022/oct/12/i-wanted-it-to-sound-like-that-feeling-of-possibility-courtney-marie-andrews-freewheeling-new-album |access-date=2024-01-20 |work=The Guardian |language=en-GB |issn=0261-3077}}</ref> These themes stem from the timing of the writing, as the songs were penned during the global [[COVID-19 pandemic]] and on the heels of the end of a longtime relationship. According to a review from [[BrooklynVegan|Brooklyn Vegan]], the record "feels like everything she's always been working towards... some of her strongest songwriting and most gorgeous sounding music yet."<ref name="Sacher">{{Cite web |last=Sacher |first=Andrew |date=2022-10-07 |title=Notable Releases of the Week (10/7) |url=https://www.brooklynvegan.com/notable-releases-of-the-week-107/ |access-date=2024-01-20 |website=BrooklynVegan |language=en-US}}</ref>
